headline: CNN Newsroom
subHeadline: 2024 U.S. Election; Rubio Being Considered by Trump for Vice President Despite Prior Criticism; Man Uses Picture of Another Passenger's Ticket to Fly; GOP Nominee to Run NC Public Schools has Called for Violence Against Democrats; Shohei Ohtani's Longtime Interpreter Fired Theft and Gambling Claims. Aired 10:30-11a ET

utterances.speaker: JIM SCIUTTO, CNN ANCHOR AND CHIEF NATIONAL SECURITY CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: They're now Trumpists.

utterances.speaker: ALAYNA TREENE, CNN REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Oh, absolutely. I mean -- and just watching that clip back again, to ever think that potentially Rubio could become Donald Trump's running mate is --

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: It's amazing.

utterances.speaker: TREENE
utterances.sentences: -- something that we would have never expected.

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TREENE
utterances.sentences: It would have been absurd to us back then. But look, I have been told by many of Donald Trump's campaign advisors that Rubio is actually real. They have acknowledged, your point Jeff, which is very, you know, astute here, is there are constitutional problems, and especially if they -- if it's a close election, this rule about having two people from the same state would become more into play. And his team very much recognizes that this is likely to be a very close election.But he has a very long list of people he is considering. It's not like Rubio is at the top here. He is someone he is seriously looking at, they say. But there's a lot of time between now and whenever Donald Trump is going to formally pick a running mate. So, I don't want to put too much stock in this. And I --

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: And there are other names on the list. Tim Scott --

utterances.speaker: TREENE
utterances.sentences: There are many other names.

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: -- Kristi Noem -- I mean, yes.

utterances.speaker: TREENE
utterances.sentences: Yes. But I will say his team says that Donald Trump and him speak frequently, people from Rubio world say that as well.

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: Interesting.

utterances.speaker: TREENE
utterances.sentences: Donald Trump likes him because he's young, he has natural charisma, he's a good speaker, he's Hispanic. Remember a key, voting bloc that Donald Trump really needs to siphon away from Joe Biden. So, those are all factors that are coming into this. But again, nothing is set in stone and this is still -- you can't really expect with Donald Trump that, you know, put too much stock in these situations because he changes his mind so quickly.

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: Yes, we've come a long way from those clips in 2016.JEFF ZELENY, CNN CHIEF U.S. NATIONAL AFFAIRS CORRESPONDENT:  Oh, the memories.

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ZELENY
utterances.sentences: The memories.

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: All right. Also, this morning, we're following a major security breach that happened at the Salt Lake City International Airport. A Texas man was arrested for boarding a Delta flight without a ticket. Court documents allege he did it by taking a photo of another passenger's boarding pass and then tried to hide in the plane's bathroom so he wouldn't be discovered.CNN's Pete Muntean joins me now to discuss. Pete, I guess it was only a matter of time before for somebody figured out this life hack. If you want to call it that.

utterances.speaker: PETE MUNTEAN, CNN AVIATION CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: It's

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: It's a little scary though.

utterances.speaker: MUNTEAN
utterances.sentences: It's sort of old school meets new school.

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MUNTEAN
utterances.sentences: And we hear of stowaways every so often where people try to sneak on board planes by getting into the baggage area or maybe into a wheel well of a plane. This method has to be one of the more crafty ones. U.S. Attorneys have charged this Texas man for sneaking on board a Delta flight bound for Austin, it happened in Salt Lake City on Sunday, which was St. Patrick's Day.Court documents say 26-year-old Wicliff Fleurizard was planning to fly standby on a Southwest flight, that flight was overbooked. So, investigators say, Fleurizard went to the gate of this Delta flight. Police reviewed the security footage which showed Fleurizard in the boarding area, taking multiple photos of multiple passengers, phones and or boarding passes while they were not looking. The criminal complaint says, Fleurizard scanned his fake ticket, boarded the plane and locked himself in the plane's bathroom and did not come out until after the plane had pushed back from the gate. Now, this plane might have worked if he did not get questioned by a flight attendant. And court documents say this, Fleurizard indicated to the flight attendant that his seat was 21F. The flight attendant verified that the passenger who was in seat 21F was the person who had purchased and had been ticketed for that seat. And it was not the criminal here, Fleurizard. So, clearly this created a lot of confusion on board. Flight attendants were pretty quickly able to figure out that this man was not on their manifest. So, then they taxied back to the gate where the police were waiting. Police say Fleurizard told them he got bumped from his original flight onto a later flight and was simply trying to get home and made a mistake. But now he's facing one count of stowing away on a vessel or aircraft, sort of, an old school charge there that can carry prison time up to five years. It is not clear yet if Fleurizard has an attorney, Jim.

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: Yes, I don't think he's going to make that mistake again.

utterances.speaker: MUNTEAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: But my -- and I -- with flights these days so full, I have to think that maybe there was a situation where he came out of the lavatory and there wasn't a seat to take. So --

utterances.speaker: MUNTEAN
utterances.sentences: That's a great point. And especially during spring break --

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: MUNTEAN
utterances.sentences: -- when things are so busy --

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MUNTEAN
utterances.sentences: -- you're really rolling the dice on that one, so.

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: It's unbelievable. All right. Pete Muntean, hopefully the airlines are going to have to update the apps, I think. a little bit.

utterances.speaker: MUNTEAN
utterances.sentences: We'll see.

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: Those boarding passes, you can do it with a screenshot. That's not good.

utterances.speaker: MUNTEAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: All right, Pete. Thanks so much.

utterances.speaker: MUNTEAN
utterances.sentences: Anytime.

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: In North Carolina, Michele Morrow was not expected to win her Republican primary race to become North Carolina's top public school official, but then last week in an upset, she did. And when she did, her extreme and controversial comments began getting attention. Last Friday, CNN's KFile reported that in the past, she has tweeted about wanting to see former President Barack Obama put in front of a firing squad, including horrific details. Morrow has also made suggestions about executing other prominent Democrats, including then-President- elect Joe Biden. She has promoted QAnon conspiracy theories as well.And CNN's Shimon Prokupecz joins me live in Raleigh, North Carolina. Shimon, you were able to catch up with Michele Morrow. What did she have to say about all of these extreme posts?

utterances.speaker: SHIMON PROKUPECZ, CNN CRIME AND JUSTICE CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Well, yes, we did, Jim. We caught up with her as she was leaving the Wake County, here in Raleigh, GOP convention. She was there for several hours. And as she was leaving, we were able to catch up with her and ask her questions about those controversial tweets. Take a look.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: Hi, Ms. Morrow. How are you?MICHELE MORROW (R), NOMINEE FOR NC SUPERINTENDENT OF PUBLIC INSTRUCTION:  Hey. I'm doing fine.

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: All right. How did it go in there?

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: Great. It went great.

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: Yes?

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: It went great, yes.

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: You feeling good?

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: Who are you guys with?

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: I'm Shimon Prokupecz. I'm with CNN.

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: Oh, have you been parked in my neighborhood by any chance?

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: We've been trying to talk to you. Yes.

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: OK. Well, you can --

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: So --

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: -- go through my campaign --

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: I understand, but I have you now.

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: Thanks.

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: So, why don't we talk now?

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: No need.

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: Why not? Well, I want to ask you --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: It's late and we're --

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: Have a good night.

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: Do you stand by what you've said about the public education system and that it needs to be destroyed?

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: No comment.

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: Do you stand by that?

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: No comment.

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: Do you understand the concern that people have --

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: No comment.

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: -- with this nomination that you now have?

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: Hey, I have a question. Do you vote North Carolina? Then keep your eyes on your own paper.

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: Well, let me ask you. I've --

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: Keep your eyes on you own paper.

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: -- I've read papers from here, too.

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: Keep your eyes on your own paper.

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: And the concerns that people have with your nomination and the things that you have said.

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: People in New York have concern over my nomination --

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: People all across -- MORROW

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: -- all across the country.

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: All across -- really?

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: Why are they concerned about North Carolina? Do you know that education is a problem in this entire country? So, maybe they need to focus on what's going on in your state of New York, which by the way, is where I grew up. Maybe they need to focus on what's going on in California, where children are not getting the education that they need. Maybe they need to focus on what they're doing in Michigan.Because right now in North Carolina, I'm focused on helping the families of North Carolina for their children to get quality education, for them to be safe, and for us to be sure that our money is going into the classroom, rather than bureaucracies. That's what I've been focusing on. That's what I've been fighting for for the last five years. Going to the General Assembly and dealing with those issues.

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: Right, but you --

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: So, that is why I am running.

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: I understand that, but you have --

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: So, you can --

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: -- said such hurtful things, too, in terms of the education system --

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: I have to tell you.

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: -- about transgender students --

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: Everyone is so done with the gotcha moment.

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: This is not a gotcha.

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: It is.

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: These are your own words, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: This has --

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: These are your own words.

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: This has nothing to do with education.

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: You have said that the former president --

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: How do you know those are my words?

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: Because you tweeted.

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: You don't have --

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: Are those not your tweets? Do you deny saying that? You have an opportunity now?

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: I am telling you --

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: Do you deny saying that?

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: I am telling you --

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: Are you denying that you said that in those tweets?

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: I am telling you --

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: Have you --

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: -- that I am going to discuss education --

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: -- have you talked about the indoctrination of children by teachers?

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: I am telling you --

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: Have you talked about that? Have you said that about students?

utterances.speaker: MORROW
utterances.sentences: Have you seen any of me going to the school board for the last five years? Because you will have my answer.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: And as you see there, Jim, she continues to deflect, at one point trying to, perhaps, even deny that she said such hurtful and really controversial things. You know, in the end, if she was to be elected, she would oversee a school system with over a million students, a million and a half students. There is a lot of concern across the state over what she has said.And certainly, for parents, certainly for many of the students who are facing a lot of difficulties and her issues on that. You know, some here in the local paper have said that she is a threat to the education system here. And certainly, there are people who feel that way. So, it's going to be interesting, obviously, to see what happens. We have some time here, but there are a lot of eyes on this election here, Jim.

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: Yes. Shimon, I mean, just to follow up. I mean, did she deny tweeting? We're posting these online messages that Barack Obama should be executed.

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: So, it's interesting. She -- you can see there at one point, she says, well, how do you know it was me, right? So, she's trying to raise, perhaps, that question. But no, she didn't deny it. She deflected, right? She tried to get me to go through her press person.

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PROKUPECZ
utterances.sentences: And she didn't. She didn't, Jim. She did not, at all, over the several times I asked her, she didn't want to address it. I mean, it is a controversial thing. It is, in some ways, very hurtful for people to who have seen her tweets, who have read her tweets. But no, she simply tried to deflect and not answer.

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: A bombshell in professional baseball. The Los Angeles Dodgers say they fired the longtime interpreter of the team's superstar, Shohei Ohtani, after he was accused by Ohtani's legal team of massive theft, reportedly tied to gambling losses.CNN's Andy Scholes joins me now with more. Andy, I mean, this is a huge thing. I guess I have to think perhaps it happens more often than you think. But what are they saying?

utterances.speaker: ANDY SCHOLES, CNN SPORTS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm not sure this happens very often, Jim --

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: Yes.
